courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Introduction to Urban Studies

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04

courses.description: This course examines the historical evolution of urban spaces from a cross-cultural perspective. The course discusses the importance of cities to the economic, cultural, and political well-being of modern societies and examines how forces such as industrialization, globalization and urbanization, among others, have affected the structure and functions of cities. Seminal theories and recent discourses in urban studies are discussed to examine how and why cities develop and change and the various roles stakeholders have played in the course of urban developments.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction: What is ‘urban’?
2. Reading urban forms
3. Evolution of urban forms
4. City as a growth machine?
5. Socio-spatial polarization
6. Privatization of public space
7. Government vs. governance
8. Asia’s World City
9. Social activism
10. Diversity & multiculturalism
11. Planning together
12. Designing together
13. Reflections…

- Reflection of teacher (including evidence from assessment)

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Introduction to Spatial Planning
courses.description: This course aims to develop a basic level of spatial planning literacy among urban studies students. The course is divided into three modules: contemporary issues in spatial planning, the history and evolution of spatial planning and spatial planning as a process; and contemporary issues in spatial planning. Through various case studies, the course sensitizes students to various pertinent spatial planning issues in the specific institutional and legal context of Hong Kong.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are expected to:
1. To develop a basic level of spatial planning literacy for life-long learning, appreciation and contribution to the urban realm.
2. To develop skills in conducting a spatial planning process.
3. To differentiate and critique good planning processes and outcomes from less desirable ones.
4. To develop a capacity to contribute creatively to sustainable spatial planning and development.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction: The nature of spatial planning
2. Who should be involved in spatial planning and development?
3. Governing spatial development
4. Climate change, resilient cities and spatial planning
5. Planning for spatial development
6. History of spatial planning
7. Spatial planning system and hierarchy of plans
8. Envisioning, planning goals and objectives
9. Plan generation
10. Plan evaluation
11. Impact assessments
12. Decision making
13. Plan implementation

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Foundation of Digital Techniques for Urban Planning and Design
courses.description: Digital media and computer-aided design techniques for urban planning and design are the foci of this course. Several computer-aided tools for urban analysis, design exploration, digital modelling and representation, professional drafting, information and concept visualization, and model making are introduced through lectures and tutorials covering history, conceptual usage, and practical skill of digital techniques. Participants must supplement lectures and tutorials by completing the relevant software tutorials on their own. The learning objective of this course is to apply and transfer skills to a variety of analytical and design tasks.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students should be able to:
1. Master the basics of free-hand sketching, technical drawing and imaging techniques.
2. Develop skills for the use of computer-aided programs for visualization, analysis and design.
3. Acquire the sensibility of graphical expression and clarity of representation.
4. Recognise, comprehend and master the complexity of three-dimensional spatial setting.
5. Apply computer-aided design skills on tasks relevant to urban planning and urban design.
6. Analyse an urban design project, with considerable complexity, and communicate ideas visually
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1&2: Basic Drawing Techniques

Week 3&4: Basic Digital Drafting Techniques (AutoCAD)

Week 5&6: Basic Digital Modelling Techniques (SketchUp)

Week 7&8: Basic Digital Illustration and Diagramming Techniques (Illustrator)

Week 9&10: Basic Digital Imagery and Rendering Techniques (Photoshop)

Week 11: Basic Digital Layout Techniques (InDesign)

Week 12: Final Project Presentation

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Dialogue with Urban Leaders
courses.description:
Leaders from the government, private sector and civil society organisations will be invited to share their visions, strategies, practices and actions regarding smart, sustainable and low-carbon developments. During the lectures, students will have opportunities to interact with the invited speakers and reflect on the qualities of urban leadership. This course aims to sensitise students to meaningful works conducted by various stakeholders, inspiring them to become urban leaders. Students are expected to learn from the speakers and discover spaces in our society where they can imbue sustainable hope for the flourishing of planet, place and people.

Students will be required to either write a reflective paper on the lectures or develop promotional materials to showcase the cases discussed in the course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are expected to:

- Recognise the importance of leadership in promoting smart, sustainable and low-carbon developments.

- Appreciate the inter-connectedness of different sectors and the actions of various stakeholders.

- Analyse factors leading to successful endeavours in promoting sustainable development.

- Reflect on the lectures and apply the materials learned in planning their studies and career.
courses.course_syllabus:
Leaders from the government, private sector and civil society organisations will be invited to dialogue with the students in a workshop format their experiences in promoting a sustainable development initiative, including topics such as:

- Vision

- Strategy to solicit support

- Turning theory and knowledge into actions

- Financing of the initiative

- Challenges

- Rewards

- Lessons learned, etc.

Field visits will also be organised in the course.

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Field Studies
courses.description: Field teaching is an integral part in the study of the urban world, which gives students an opportunity to understand the real-world situations and to supplement what they have learnt from the lectures. This course is designed in the format of a study trip in Hong Kong or a big overseas city. The objectives are three-fold: (1) to introduce students to different techniques in the collection of field data; (2) to help students identify, understand and explain urban problems; and (3) to provide an opportunity for students to work as a team in problem-solving. Students are required to participate actively in all activities throughout the study trip and to submit an individual report afterwards.
courses.course_syllabus: A number of study themes will be proposed for the field study. Students will be organized into groups to undertake research during the field study.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
- Qualitative feedback from students/discussion forums

courses.required_readings: Will be assigned according to the destination of the field trip.

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Belt and Road for Collaborative Modernization
courses.description:
(UGEC2917 is double-coded with URSP2010.)

The Belt and Road initiative (BRI) refers to the Silk Road Economic Belt and the 21st Century Maritime Silk Road. It is a significant development strategy proposed by the Chinese Government spanning approximately 60 countries in Asia, Eastern Europe, Middle East and Africa, with a total population of 4.4 billion. This initiative takes advantage of global transportation routes, core cities, and key ports to build international economic co-operation corridors. The effective operation and management of the BRI require collaboration among a broad range of disciplines comprising civil engineering, material science, government operations, economics and finance, social and political science, and environmental science. A critical and multi-disciplinary understanding of the BRI can provide insights into basic requirements, geopolitical impact, physical barriers, and sustainability potential of the infrastructural projects it proposes to undertake and help relevant stakeholders address large-scale and complex challenges in the lifecycle management of those infrastructure projects. This course involves forward-looking perspectives to assess, predict, influence and enhance the in/direct network effects and benefits of the BRI on the cities, urban systems and peoples of the Belt and Road region.
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction

1. Globalization in Perspective: introduction of globalization as a term, process and ideology.

2. Historical Silk Road: historical origins of the Silk Road; continuities and shifts in terms of Maritime Silk Road, interactions and encounters along the Silk Road.

Global Implications

3. Geopolitical Shifts: branding and popularizing the Belt and Road Initiative; imperial histories and ambitions informing the initiative.

4. Eastern and Western Perspectives: the opportunities and challenges arising from Belt and Road Initiative with reference to the European Recovery Program; the geopolitical theories of Alfred Mahan, Halford Mackinder and Henry Kissinger; the philosophy of Confucius and Taoists.

Facilities Connectivity

5. Construction Management in BRI countries: risk management in international construction joint ventures and overseas development institute; large-scale transnational high-speed railway construction projects.

6. Green and Sustainable Urbanization: In search of better livability in BRI cities: Liveability in dense and vertical cities; green finance; carbon auditing and carbon trading; green strategies for achieving sustainable development goals.

Unimpeded Trade

7. Trading, Logistic, and Professional Service: Hong Kong as regional BRI centre for trading, logistic and professional services; manufacture shifting and upgrading experience in ASEAN economies.

8. The Energy Market: energy market opportunities and uncertainties in Northeast, Southeast, Central Asia and Africa; global oil and gas markets; renewable and sustainable energy goals.

Financial Integration

9. The Bond Market: infrastructure financing; international bond market and Hong Kong’s debt market; corporate social responsibility on Green Bond Issuance; the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank and the Silk Road Fund.

10. International Settlement: currency wars and special drawing rights; consumerism and RMB internationalization; Hong Kong as the offshore RMB centre; the New Development Bank.

Regional Responses

11. Middle East: geopolitics and energy nexus; religious and national concerns.

12. Central and Eastern Europe: rail and maritime connectivities; integrating trade and resisting xenophobia.

13. India: regional rivalry, economic integration and border disputes

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: (Re) Claiming the City
courses.description:
Increasingly uneven and intensified processes of urbanization simultaneously generate serious challenges and exciting opportunities for urban populations across the globe. Contemporary cities are as much spaces of resonance, innovation, and emancipation as sites of violence, pollution, and alienation. This course revolves around the distinctive rhythms, experiences, and dynamics of urban life. What gives urban living its distinct characteristics? What current social, economic, and political problems deserve the attention of urban inhabitants? Which issues generate the greatest discord and motivate full coordination among different actors involved in governing cities?

As urban life is characterized by both cosmopolitan conviviality and immense inequality, in this course students will learn about different modes of coexistence and exclusion in contemporary cities. Globalizing forms of urban protest arising from struggles over urban resources, space, and decision-making mechanisms will be investigated. By highlighting the complex and contested dynamics of urban life, the course will help students situate and interpret their everyday urban experiences at the intersection of multiple and interconnected flows, networks, and scales that are produced by the city and that produce it.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students will be able to:

1. Comprehend general debates, themes, and concepts in critical urban theory,
2. Apply key concepts and theories reflexively to their own experiences in the city,
3. Gain a critical understanding of urban politics, social movements, and public space,
4. Use qualitative methods as a tool for interpreting the struggles over urban governance, contested claims to urban space, and symbolic construction of city as text.
courses.course_syllabus:
The following topics are included in the course:

* *PART I: EXPERIENCING THE CITY**

Topic 1: Town and Countryside

Topic 2: Modernity and Urbanization

Topic 3: City Culture(s)

Topic 4: Narrating the City

Topic 5: Urban Experiences

* *PART II: GOVERNING THE CITY**

Topic 6: Cities and Democracy

Topic 7: Living with Others

Topic 8: The Multicultural City

Topic 9: Changing Actors of Urban Governance

* *PART III: (RE)CLAIMING THE CITY**

Topic 10: Divided Lives, Security, Inequality

Topic 11: Right to the City

Topic 12: Globalization of Urban Protest

Topic 13: Glocalization of Urban Protest

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Urban Cultures
courses.description: Cities are dynamic sites of cultural production, interaction and transformation. Everyday experience of urban areas is characterized by specific social relations, spatial configurations and temporalities, while cities are home to various cultures emerging from multiple axes of difference. This course aims to introduce students to various ways in which urban life shapes and is shaped by cultural processes, institutions and practices. Students will learn about distinct urban senses, experiences and subjectivities only found in modern cities. We will explore how various cultural identities are (re)produced and negotiated by groups with different ethnic, religious and class backgrounds. To this end, we will look at the relationship between cultural background and inequality, segregation and domination. Students will further discover the ways in which cultural difference is implicated in symbolic economies of cities through urban regeneration and heritage conservation projects, city branding, and geographies of consumption.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students should be able to:

1. Understand specific cultural experiences and structures only found in modern cities,

2. Explain the dialectical relationship between cultural formations and urban space,

3. Critically compare and contrast the relationship between representation, power and inequality in cities,

4. Develop an appreciation for multicultural conviviality and hybridity towards synthesizing principles of an inclusive and just society,

5. Analyze the ways in which cultural identities, creative energies and urban heritage are implicated in urban economies.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Culture of/in Cities

2. Modernity and urban life

3. Spatiality of the urban realm

4. City as text

5. Narrating the city

6. Urban senses and rhythms

7. Everyday city

8. Gendering urbanity

9. Multicultural cities

10. Cinematic cities

11. Cities and consumption

12. Cultural industries and creative class

13. Urban heritage and tourism

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Real Estate and Construction Economics
courses.description: This course introduces students to the main tools and concepts of real estate/construction economics. It covers the relationship between real estate and the macro-economy, real estate finance, investment appraisal, taxation, demand and supply, and market dynamics. It deals with both residential and commercial real estate. It also introduces to students the institutions within which the construction industry and its professions operate and interact with, so as to enable students to identify and analyze industry-wide problems based on an understanding of the market structure, performance and behavior of the industry.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are expected to:

1. Understand the roles of the real estate and construction sectors in the economy.

2. Use macro-economic theories to analyze the role of real estate and construction sectors.

3. Apply financial theories and models for real estate investment analysis and decision-making.

4. Synthesize and apply knowledge in various types of real estate management.

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Socially Engaged Art
courses.description: Over the past thirty years, artists from various disciplines have choreographed imaginative encounters in the urban realm using social dynamics to catalyse aesthetics experiences. These citizen-artists committed to shoulder responsibilities beyond the object of art, emancipating art's subjects and its transformative agencies to empower the public at large in relational gestures through city games, community theatres, silent university, urban interventions, environmental activism and digital-placemaking …etc. This course will introduce students to a few key concepts in the field of socially engaged art practices. They will learn how to plan relational art projects in collaboration with a community they wish to engage. By applying art's transformative capacities to heal the pain points manifested in the public arena interdependently, students will be exposed to new methodologies to experiment with cultural production, empathize with different stakeholders’ conflicting interests and co-create imaginative outcome through the process of art-making.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Appreciate different modes of contemporary cultural production both locally and in other parts of the world.
2. Understand key concepts in the field of socially engaged art practices
3. Analyse pain points of our city and being able to apply relational gestures for empowering community.
4. Develop empathy and active listening skills to respect all stakeholders’ interests and use imagination and dialogues to resolve conflicts.
5. Build capacities to work inter-relationally and collaborate with government, the market, and the civil society at juncture of co-creation.
6. Value the openness of relational art, life and our environment as active-evolving processes and not as a closed object of art inside the glass box.
courses.course_syllabus:
PHASE 1: DETECT THE RELEVANT ISSUE

1. Introduction: The (un)definition of art and mode of contemporary practices
2. A portrait of the artist as a public entity and art as the social thermometer
3. Dissonance of our world - pain points, errors, cracks in the wall and the void revealed by the evidentiary processes
4. Sharing and team forming

PHASE 2: PROCESSES AND TECHNIQUES LEARNING

1. Socially-Engaged Art (SEA): origin, historical development and global overview
2. Let time brew it: rural, urban, industrial approaches of SEA in local context
3. Guest lecture: local practitioners sharing
4. Condition for community empowerment
5. The transformative power of art: poetic, disruptive, connective, symbolic and healing

PHASE 3: CO-CREATION

1. Curious methods to orchestrate relations: conduct art, city games, community theatre, silent university, climate activism
2. Students’ socially-engaged projects are to be performed or activated publicly
3. Presentation
4. Collaboration and its discontents: limitation and future development of SEA in HK

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Understanding City Through Field Trip Studies
courses.description: This course explores the distinctive role of “field trip” in understanding and researching the city we live through a series of guided tours. It stresses that engaging urban issues ‘out there’ is more than a complementary tool of collecting data, but also a reflexive practice that enables affective learning, changing our preconceptions, inspiring us to consider possible interventions. Selected tours covering cutting-edge urban development issues in town are provided to demonstrate the diverse functions of field-based learning in different urban milieu. It will examine the changing concepts of the ‘field’ in future city, and how we can represent urban problems by organizing a framework of destinations and experience.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students should be able to:

1. Appreciate the diversity of field-based learning practices in different urban and rural settings.

2. Understand the role and functions of field trips in researching dynamic urban environments.

3. Develop an ability to identify and analyse problems and challenges through field-based learning.

4. Represent interpreted urban issues through curating field trips in a systematic way.
courses.course_syllabus:
Field trips will be carried out with digital devices and will be conducted according to social distancing policy of the time. If the pandemic situation does not allow physical field trip, the instructor will conduct online field trip to facilitate students' learning.

1. Introduction

2. Fieldtrip As Method

3. Preparation for Trip 1-2

4. Trip 1: Creating Urban Economy

5. Trip 2: City Nature in Crisis

6. Preparation for Trip 3

7. Trip 3 (Compulsory): Questioning Urban Archipelago

8. Organize Your Own Trip and conducting field trips under difficult situations

9. Preparation for Trip 4-5

10. Trip 4: Frontiers in Urban Redevelopment

11. Trip 5: Imagining Northern Borderland

12. Proposal Presentation

13. Conclusion: Limitations and Possibilities of the Urban 'Field'

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Urban Planning and Design Practices in China
courses.description: China's urban planning profession is developing and maturing rapidly, and China could be said to be one of the fastest urbanizing Regions in the world. World renowned urban planning and architectural firms have located offices in China to take advantage of the abundance of Projects. Along with the Local Design Institutes, they design and implement various levels of planning and design and practices, which not only change the appearance of the cityscape, but also enrich the contents of our planning profession. Hong Kong’s status as an important core city in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area (GBA) necessitates our urban planning students to systematically understand the urban planning practices in mainland China. A knowledge of the correlation of urban planning between Hong Kong and mainland China will be essential for Hong Kong to take advantage of the opportunities of GBA in the years ahead.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction of urban planning in China (Government/ Private sector/ LDI collaboration, etc.)
2. Macro-scale statutory and strategic planning 1 (National spatial planning/ Tourism planning/ Village revitalization planning)
3. Macro-scale statutory and strategic planning 2 (National spatial planning/ Tourism planning/ Village revitalization planning)
4. Medium-scale statutory and strategic planning 1 (Land Use planning/ Tourism town planning)
5. Medium-scale statutory and strategic planning 2 (Land Use planning/ Tourism town planning)
6. Medium scale urban design 1 (Urban design framework, Marketing planning)
7. Medium scale urban design 2 (Urban design framework, Marketing planning)
8. Micro scale urban design (Statutory detailed master planning/ Urban design guidelines/ Detailed marketing planning)
9. Design communication workshop: national spatial planning & land use zoning plan
10. Design communication workshop: detailed planning and urban design
11. Design communication workshop: planning and urban design competition
12. Presentation skills in Chinese and English
13. New trends and hot topics of urban planning and design in China

courses.title: Urban Sustainability

courses.description: This course explores theories and practices pertaining to urban sustainability, focusing on the fundamental issue that gives rise to the notion of sustainability—the integrity of the Earth’s life-supporting system. It examines global and local environmental issues, as well as consequential socioeconomic problems, arising from urban development and continuous urban growth. It also explores existing and emerging approaches to urban sustainability. Throughout the course, students will be challenged to contemplate on the core of the quest of urban sustainability—the relationship between humans and nature.
courses.course_syllabus:
1: Defining sustainability

2: Environmental problems of urban development

3: Urban metabolism

4: Urban air quality

5: Urban climate

6: Urban ecology and hydrology

7: Sustainability issues in Hong Kong

8: Ecosystem services and sustainable cities

9: Urban resilience to natural hazards and climate change

10: Design and planning approaches to urban sustainability

11: Socio-economic issues in urban sustainability

12: Challenges in moving towards sustainable cities in Asia & Concluding remarks

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Urban Economic Studies
courses.description: Urban economic studies examines the locational choices of firms and households and their effects on the formation of cities of different sizes. The course investigates the positive and negative externalities of cities and challenges students to apply basic economic principles to resolve urban issues.
courses.course_syllabus:
Key topics to be included:

• Urban economic development: determinants and processes

• Spatial arrangements of firms and households:

o Land markets in cities

o Development of firms in cities

o Housing markets in cities

o Urban transportation system

• Positive and negative externalities of cities of various scales

o Economy of scale and urban efficiency

o Urban poverty and polarization

o Gentrification

o Congestion and pollution

• Public policy responses

o Government policies

o Local public finance

o Tax issues

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Urban Design and Place Making Studio
courses.description: This studio course is concerned with the multidisciplinary field and practice of urban design. It includes a review of historical approaches to urban design and current movements in the field, as well as place making, theories of good city form, scales of urban design, implementation approaches, and challenges and opportunities for the discipline.
courses.course_syllabus:
• What is urban design and what are the activities of urban designers?

• How can we sense and evaluate urban design and urban places?

• How can urban design facilitate participatory urban processes?

• What are contemporary limitations and challenges of urban design?

• How can urban designers develop approaches to address urgent contemporary issues?

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Studies of Cities in Comparative Perspective
courses.description: This course introduces students to the studies of comparative urbanism. Urban studies have strong west-centric and modernist biases that designate specific cities as universal models for city-proper status and/or as harbingers of new urban forms. Drawing on postcolonial and poststructuralist critiques, the course aims at aiding future urbanists to explore a world of cities beyond developmentalist perspectives and the fetishization of novelty. The students will instead learn to become aware of and analyze the complex and interconnected manifestations of urban forms and experiences across different times and places.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Cities in History

2. Historicizing Development

3. Divergent Pathways into Urbanization

4. Multiple Modernities

5. Comparative Urbanism

6. (Post)Colonial Cities

7. Socialist and Capitalist Cities

8. World Cities and Global Cities

9. Ordinary Cities

10. Neoliberal Influences

11. Megacities

12. Sprawl Cities

13. Smart Urbanism

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Field Studies I
courses.description: Field teaching is an integral part in the study of the urban world, which gives students an opportunity to understand the real-world situations and to supplement what they have learnt from the lectures. This course is designed in the format of a study trip in Hong Kong or a big overseas city. The objectives are three-fold: (1) to introduce students to different techniques in the collection of field data; (2) to help students identify, understand and explain urban problems; and (3) to provide an opportunity for students to work as a team in problem-solving. Students are required to participate actively in all activities throughout the study trip and to submit an individual report afterwards.
courses.course_syllabus: A number of study themes will be proposed for the field study. Students will be organized into groups to undertake research during the field study.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
- Qualitative feedback from students/discussion forums

- Mid-term and end of term course evaluation

- Reflection of teacher (including evidence from assessment)
courses.required_readings: Will be assigned according to the destination of the field trip.
courses.recommended_readings: Will be assigned according to the destination of the field trip.

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Urban Visualisation Studio
courses.description: Digital design media and geographic information systems for urban planning and design are core topics addressed in this studio course. Digital instruments for analyzing, drafting, modeling, testing, visualization, and fabrication are introduced through lectures, demonstration and studio-based exercises covering theoretical concepts and practical skill building training. Participants must supplement lectures and tutorials by completing relevant software tutorials and studio-based practice independently. The learning objective of this studio course is to apply and transfer skills to various analytical and design tasks.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this studio course, students should be able to:
- Learn and transfer skills in the use of digital software for visualisation, analyses and design;
- Apply these skills to a range of tasks in the field of urban planning and design; and
- Understand basic knowledge of current digital environments and trends and have the ability to continue self-learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
The aim of this course is for participants to become eloquent in the use of digitally aided techniques for urban planning and design. Participants shall be able to explore ideas, analyze spatial data, and present and communicate design concepts electronically by employing a variety of digital and mixed media.
Participants who complete this course will have a broad knowledge of various computing instruments and techniques for analyses and design. They will have sufficient practical skills allowing the immediate application in their urban design studios and other courses.

courses.required_readings: Respective software manuals and tutorials of each software application presented in the course.
courses.recommended_readings: Respective software manuals and tutorials of each software application presented in the course.

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Urban Form, Sense of Place and Well-Being
courses.description:
Urbanisation has changed the natural landscape into human habitats, shaping people’s daily lives and their modes of interactions. Technological developments have allowed the human race to ‘overcome’ many environmental constraints and gradually people have developed their urban settlements for functional purposes, forgetting the important relationships between forms and people’s sense of well-being. The popularization of smartphones, internet and social media further disconnected people from experiencing a place fully. What are urban forms? How do urban forms affect our sense of a place? How is our sense of place related to our subjective sense of multi-faceted well-being? This course aims to equip students with an ability to understand and study the relationships of urban forms, sense of place and sense of well-being so that they can (re)create urban forms that are conducive to community sense of place and multi-faceted well-being.

Through interactive class activities, the design and conduct of a team survey and individual essay writing, students learn not only about the importance of urban forms in shaping people’s sense of place and community and the multifaceted well-being, but also how to design a questionnaire survey to research and analyse their relationships and formulate suggestions to enhance the situation of local neighbourhoods.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking the course, students are expected to:
1. Compare and contrast various typologies of urban form and their relationships with people’s diversified sense of place/community and multifaceted well-being
2. Cultivate a capacity to differentiate desirable urban forms from less desirable ones for multifaceted well-being
3. Generalise the relationships among urban forms, sense of place and well-being
4. Identify principles that can create and design urban forms that promote better and strong sense of place and community
courses.course_syllabus:
• Urban form and health
• Evolution of urban forms
• Urban design principles
• Sense of place
• Sense of community
• Biophilia and physical well-being
• Sociopetal space and psychological and social well-being
• Resilient communities
• Survey design
• Field work
• Sharing & discussion of results

- Reflection of teacher (including evidence from assessment)

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Recommoning
courses.description: More than two centuries of market driven capitalist developments in various parts of the world have brought much progress to humankind, but such growth has also led to formidable global environmental and socio-economic challenges. This course attempts to rethink about economic developments that centre around the wellbeing of people and the environment. The course explores ways people across the globe are building community economies based on ethical concerns for more sustainable and equitable futures. It aims to provide the theoretical grounding to re-imagine economic development and practical skills in recommoning—organising community-based development interventions that promote the well-being of people, place and planet.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking the course, students should be able to:

1. appreciate the diversity of economic practices that are found locally and in other parts of the world

2. compare the different theoretical approaches used to frame these diverse economic practices

3. compare and contrast the ethical, ecological and equity concerns of different economic practices

4. analyse the contribution of diverse economic practices to more sustainable and equitable forms of development

5. identify the types of policies that might foster diverse economic practices that align with the principles of recommoning
courses.course_syllabus:
• What is development?

• What is the economy?

• Theoretical approaches to economic development

• Surviving well

• Distributing surplus

• Encountering others

• Re-commoning

• Investing in futures

• Policies for economic diversity

• Case studies

• Whither recommoning

courses.description: This course provides an in-depth analysis of specific topics in urban studies that supplements other courses offered by the Programme. The topics selected are of great significance to urban development and planning. The content of the course will vary with the instructor. Important topics will include the theories and practices of urban development, planning and design.

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Housing Issues and Policy
courses.description: This course aims to engage students in understanding and analysing complex housing issues and to prepare them in identifying and formulating integrated policy options for the recognised problems. Students will explore issues and policy realms related to different forms and categories of housing provided by the public and private sectors in specific socio-economic contexts. They will be encouraged to explore sustainable policy options and design to meet the housing needs of different socio-economic groups.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction

Approaches

2. Housing as a commodity

3. Housing as a right

4. Housing provision in public and private sectors (different designs for different classes and households)

5. Housing behaviour at different geographical scales

Housing in the Urban Context

6. The economics of housing

7. The institutions of housing

8. The social dimension of housing

9. The environmental and physical dimension of housing

Policies

10. Affordable housing and housing subsidies

11. Regeneration and gentrification

12. Governments’ roles in the housing sector: Western perspectives

13. Governments’ roles in the housing sector: Asia’s experience

14. Conclusion: sustainable housing policy?

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Advanced Urban Design Studio
courses.description: This course is a design studio, in which students learn urban design concepts and tools for designing the urban built environment. The students work closely with the instructor to develop an urban design scheme for a study site, learning how to strategically organize major urban design elements, such as buildings, streets and open spaces, and infrastructure, taking into account a plethora of associated socioeconomic and environmental factors. The students go through a series of exercises, including precedent studies, site survey, site analysis, mapping, programming, model making, conceptualization, visualization, oral presentation, etc.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To develop design skills in formulating an urban design scheme that incorporates major physical elements of the city, i.e. buildings, open spaces, streets, transport, and infrastructure, to meet the economic/ social/environmental needs of the community under the framework of SDGs (particularly SDG 11).
2. To identify issues/problems/opportunities of the study site and resolve into creative urban design proposals.
3. To apply verbal and visual communication skills for effective representation of urban design concepts / solutions.
4. To demonstrate critical thinking in urban design, urban management, and community building.
courses.course_syllabus: Specific syllabus will be defined by teacher in response to current urban issues and developments.

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Sustainable Urban Transport
courses.description: Sustainability issues are increasingly addressed in the planning and development of urban transport. Our understanding of sustainable development has changed the ways we handle passenger and freight transport. This course will introduce urban transportation issues from the social, economic, and environmental perspectives. Transport policies, programs, and tools for sustainable communities will be introduced. While sustainable mobility and freight movement will be discussed in the course, the focus will be on issues related to personal mobility and accessibility.
courses.course_syllabus:
Tentative major topics include:

- Defining Sustainable Transport

- Transport and Urban Form

- Mobility vs. Accessibility

- Transit-oriented Development (TOD)

- Urban Transportation Planning Process

- Public Transportation

- Transportation Demand Management

- Land Use and Travel Behavior

- Transport and Public Health

- Bicycle and Pedestrian Planning

- Transport and the Environment

- Carsharing

- Freight Transport

- Transport and Energy

- Social and Environmental Justice

- Urban Transport in the Developing World

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Essentials of the Land Development Process
courses.description: This course provides a comprehensive understanding of a land development process, including programme planning, budgeting and financing, site selection and property acquisition, regulatory clearance, design, construction and completion. Students will also be sensitized to cutting edge knowledge of sustainable development theories and practices in a typical land development process.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students will be able to:

• Identify comprehensively the interrelated components that constitute the intricate land development process

• Apply knowledge learned in class to critically analyse and evaluate land development projects

• Generalize the roles of key stakeholders in a land development process

• Reflect on the budgeting and financing aspects of land development projects

• Compare and contrast various regulatory regimes in governing the land development process

• Critically review the importance of design and construction in the delivery of sustainable land development projects
courses.course_syllabus:
• What is a land development process?

• Programme planning: the concept, seed capital, professional team

• Budgeting and financing: valuation, market analysis, location, feasibility, risk analysis, capital

• Site selection and property acquisition: site analysis, land acquisition

• Government permit and approval: regulatory framework

• Design: professional team, design, management professional

• Construction: contract work, quality control

• Completion: completion, building permit, certificate of occupancy

• Development control regimes in Hong Kong

• Public Works Programme in Hong Kong

• Real estate development

• Integrated rail-property development

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Field Studies II
courses.description: The field studies concentrate on the understanding of places through direct observation and personal experience. The course gives opportunity to study specific urban settings and their spatial and cultural contexts. Students analyse on-site the impact of design and planning decisions on liveability, vitality and sense of place. The course trains techniques of documentation and analysis such as mapping, drawing and photographing. The field studies are conducted in Hong Kong, mainland China or overseas according to specific themes.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are expected to:

• Apply urban studies, planning and design theories and analytical tools in the field study. compare and contrast context-based societal issues and formulate related research questions

• Reflect on the diversified interests of various local stakeholders

• Analyse urban issues with reference to theories and international practices

• Formulate practical solutions considering local constraints and opportunities
courses.course_syllabus: A number of study themes will be proposed for the field study. Students will be organized into groups to undertake research during the field study.

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Designing Smart Cities
courses.description: Are smart cities just about deploying technologies to improve a city’s infrastructure? Does the concept of ‘smart city’ go beyond improving hard-ware, combating climate change and closing the gaps of socio-economic disparities? Students in this course will review how smart cities in other parts of the world are designed. With a synthesized framework on the various aspects of smart city developments, students will engage different stakeholders in a district to audit their understanding of the utility of different smart technologies and examine what can be done to improve their life and livelihood. Based on the findings, students have to design a basket of measures to nurture a smart community.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking the course, students are expected to:
1. compare and contrast different modes of planning and designing smart cities
2. anlayse and project development of smart technologies and their applications in the context of Hong Kong
3. develop skills in engaging the general public to evaluate their understanding and demand for smart technologies
4. revisit the Hong Kong Planning Standards and Guidelines, relevant ordinances or even design strategies, policies, institutions or measures to enable the use of technologies in meeting people’s daily needs and creating smart communities
courses.course_syllabus:
• Introduction: designing smart cities
• Planning smart cities
• Overseas case studies
• Smart technologies
• A synthesized framework on smart cities
• Community engagement
• Field work
• Formulation of smart community design
• Presentations

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Urban Regeneration
courses.description:
Urban regeneration is important for most developed cities including Hong Kong given the lack of developable land in urban area. Urban regeneration offers some unique opportunities for the re-planning of some developed space for a better environment, where architectural conservation, landscape improvement, and better urban design can be implemented. However, owing to the many stakeholders, economic reasons and the diversified concerns, the process is also creating major debates in the community.

Besides the deliberation on the theoretical concepts, the course will go through the technical process of urban regeneration which includes land use planning, architectural conservation, landscape and environmental improvement and urban design. This will enable students to understand the mechanism of urban transformation process thoroughly and may inspire them to further their studies in specific professional fields.

On the social side, redevelopment as a major tool of urban regeneration often disturbs and uproots existing residents, small local businesses and their social networks. Together with the issue of compensation this has been causing major public concerns. The issues are further complicated by the recent debate on the social responsibilities and economic sustainability of the Urban Renewal Authority.

This course aims not only at letting students understand the process of urban regeneration but their ability to analyze and assess the issues objectively and critically.
courses.course_syllabus:
- The theories and process of urban regeneration, the roles and functions of land use planning; landscape improvement and architectural conservation

- Architectural conservation

- Urban environment and landscape design

- Planning and place making for our urban environment

- The economic and social impacts of urban regeneration

- Case studies of urban regeneration in reviving our environment

- Urban regeneration and economics

- Urban regeneration and social impacts

- Urban and sustainable planning through urban regeneration

- The outlook of urban regeneration

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Valuations for Sustainable Development
courses.description: This course aims to equip students to conduct sustainability valuation. The basic principles, methods and tools of sustainability valuation will be covered to assess the socio-economic and ecological costs and benefits of projects, policies and plans. The course covers ecological, social and economic valuation theories, methodologies and case studies.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students will:

* Understand the concepts of sustainability and valuation and their importance.
* Understand and develop skills in valuing economic activities from different perspectives.
* Appreciate and apply concepts and methods of valuing ecosystem services.
* Explore theories and methodologies in valuing social impacts.
* Synthesize sustainability valuation to inform decision-making in the planning and development processes.
* Develop a capacity to compare and contrast different valuation methods and generate new approaches to sustainability valuation.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Sustainability
2. Valuation
3. Economic valuation: Concepts and Mathematics
4. Economic valuation:

* Market approach
* Income approach
* Cost approach

5. Economic valuation:

* Economics of property value
* Valuation of investment property
* Valuation of development property

6. Economic valuation:

* Valuation for financial statements
* Valuation for land and property taxation
* Valuations for expropriation

7. Economic valuation:

* Valuation process and governance
* Valuation variance
* Risk and optionality

8. Ecological valuation:

* Natural capital
* Ecosystem services
* Carbon pricing

9. Ecological valuation methodologies and case studies: life cycle assessment, market and non-market approaches, revealed preference methods (e.g. hedonic pricing), stated preference methods (e.g. contingent valuation) and cost-based methods (e.g. replacement cost).

10. Social valuation:

* Stakeholder engagement
* Social impact assessment
* Social return on investment

11. Social valuation methodologies and case studies: social accounting, sustainability reporting, using proxy values, willing-to-pay, market values and stakeholder values, impact pathways (inputs, activities, outputs, outcomes and impacts)
12. Sustainability valuation in decision-making: case studies
13. Reporting, ethical considerations and challenges in sustainability valuation

1. Qualitative feedback from students/discussion forums
2. Mid-term and end-of-term course evaluation
3. Reflection of teacher (including evidence from assessment)

courses.description: Students are required to produce a final Capstone Thesis related to their areas of concentration under the guidance of their supervisors. Students are expected to apply appropriate skills and research methodologies to comprehend and analyse the causes of the identified urban problem and appraise and formulate creative and sustainable policy, planning, design or management solutions. Part I of the two capstone theses (URSP4001 and 4002) concentrates on the identification of a research problem, the formulation of a theoretical framework and proposal writing, including the research design and data collection methods. Part II aims at data analysis, interpretation of research results and thesis writing.

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Urban Studies Capstone Project I
courses.description: Students are required to produce a final Capstone Project (URSP4003 and 4004) related to their areas of concentration under the guidance of their supervisors. Students are expected to apply appropriate urban design skills to creatively and critically address a spatial issue of urbanism. Part I (URSP4003) of the two capstone projects concentrates on the identification of an existing urban design issue—either a city-wide or a localized issue—that has not been effectively addressed, the review of existing discourses and design projects relevant to the identified issue, and a comprehensive site analysis. Part II (URSP4004) focuses on the development of an urban design scheme that addresses this issue while pushing the boundaries of the established discourses and design approaches to achieve more sustainable and creative solutions.

courses.subject: URSP
courses.title: Urban Planning Theory and Practice
courses.description: This course aims to engage students to critically reflect on urban planning theories and practices as processes shaped by different stakeholders in varying institutional settings. Students are encouraged to compare and contrast various planning theories and their implications for the possible value positions and practical actions by the government, the market and the civil society groups in the planning process. They are expected to apply the theoretical perspectives to analyse and evaluate existing planning practices and suggest ways to improve them.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are expected:

•To compare and contrast the various approaches to interpret the functions of urban planning and their implications on the roles of the government, the market and the civil society in the planning process;
•To identify and reflect on the value and theoretical issues involved in the distribution of resources through urban planning within an institutional setting; and

•To recognize the importance of urban planning theories and the formulation of their own value positions in evaluating the actually existing urban planning mechanisms and in guiding practices.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Urban planning as a process

2. Hierarchy of plans
